descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Jerry Stackhouse led a balanced scoring attack with 17 points as the Detroit Pistons dumped the Los Angeles Clippers, 105-92, to win their third straight game entering the All-Star break.
article.headline: Jones, Williamson scored 15 apiece off bench
article.linkText: Clippers bench-pressed by 49 points from Pistons' reserves
article.story:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons can credit their reseves for their latest victory.
Williamson

Jones

Damon Jones and Corliss Williamson each scored 15 points in a reserve role to lead the Pistons to a 105-92 over the Los Angeles Clippers on Thursday night. The Pistons' subs outscored the Clippers' reserves 49-24 and keyed Detroit's decisive fourth-quarter surge. "Our bench did a great job for us," Pistons coach Rick Carlisle said. "Winning this one will make the break a lot more enjoyable." Jerry Stackhouse added 17 points for the Pistons, who beat the Clippers for the eighth time in nine games at the Palace. Elton Brand scored 25 points and Jeff McInnis added 23 for the Clippers. "We had a chance to win, but Detroit's a really solid ball club," Brand said. "They had a lot of guys step up and hit some big shots." Trailing by a point at the start of the fourth quarter, Carlisle elected to stay with his reserves rather than put his starters back into the game. The move paid off. The Pistons used an 18-5 run to take a 95-82 lead with 5:33 remaining. Jones hit two 3-pointers in the surge and Barry added a 3 that bounced off the rim twice before going in. "I was really hot, so I was going to keep shooting," Jones said. "But it wasn't just the bench, our whole team had a big game tonight." Carlisle put the starters back in the game when the Clippers closed within 95-87. The Clippers then began fouling Ben Wallace, who entered the game shooting 45.6 percent from line. Wallace made 3 of 8 free throws and helped the Pistons seal the victory. Wallace wasn't bothered by the strategy, which was also used by the Orlando Magic and the Clippers last season. Stackhouse, however, was angry. "That's cheap -- that's not basketball," Stackhouse said. "You should try to win the game on the floor -- make more plays than the other team. You don't have to do stuff like that." Clippers coach Alvin Gentry, who coached Detroit from 1997-2000, was unapologetic. "I love Ben Wallace, and Ben knows that," he said. "There's not a coach in the NBA that wouldn't like him on their team. But if he's a poor foul shooter, obviously, we're going to foul him and see if he'll miss the shots." Corey Maggette scored 16 points in the first half and the Clippers led 50-49 at the break. Detroit used a 10-0 run in the third quarter to seize the lead. Wallace had six points and two blocks in the run. Los Angeles rallied to take a 72-71 lead by the end of the quarter, but couldn't hang on to sweep the season series. "They did to us what we did to them the last time we played them," Gentry said. "They were really good in the fourth quarter and they made all the plays. We hung around, but they are a good team."

Game notes
Two Clippers found out prior to the game that they will be heading to Philadelphia for All-Star weekend. Brand is replacing Shaquille O'Neal in the All-Star game, while Miles will take Stromile Swift's spot in the Rookie Challenge. ... Stackhouse had just two points in the first half. ... Brand and Zeljko Rebraca each picked up technical fouls for a fourth-quarter scuffle that also involved Barry and Miles.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
